body:
I think it's unreasonable to assume that everyone connects with devices that are their own.

If you want centralized cluster management, you might want to look at Arigi.

What in my proposal assumes that the devices are owned by the same user?

To prevent unwanted remote config changes, the user should enable authentication.  Displaying a link to the admin GUI only simplifies the process for those cases where remote access is even possible because the remote user already has the credentials.  The most common default case would not even allow remote GUI access, so it only affects users who already consciously opened it up.

My only assumption is that this share of users will likely want to connect to their remote GUI from another syncthing node within the cluster, instead of some random computer.

It would be fairly trivial to do this; we already have the IP visible in the GUI, all we need to do is guess the port and print the link. 

The more useful thing to do would be to (optionally) allow API/GUI access proxied over the sync connection we already have. This would work over relays and through proxies etc. I don’t necessarily think we should implement that either. 

(For *Arigi* specifically I’d like to be able to tell Syncthing to push events and logs to a management station HTTPS address and accept API commands in the returned response, turning the request/response cycle on its head. We should probably not implement that either.)

What do you mean by "guess the port"?  It's not really standardized, but could be announced by the remote device, as I am suggesting.

Of course, sharing the sync connection would be great, but sounds like a lot of code complexity.

As for Arigi, it seems to be a commercial service.  One more level on top which needs configuration.  Opening firewalls for remote GUI access can already be quite complex, so I am trying to make things easier once the remote access is configured.

Yeah I just said guess because at the moment it’s not communicated. It certainly could be, but that also means we ought to try upnp to get an external port mapping for it, for example. We certainly shouldn’t do that without the user’s permission.

The simplest possible solution I can think of, which would work with statically configured ports or forwards, would be to let you configure the api port on a remote device. When it’s connected via a non-relay method we could then show a GUI link in the device section.

Well it's better than nothing, but an unnecessary extra step if the GUI port could be advertised on connection.

What about my proposal, show the link after trying to open an HTTPS connection to it and match the certificate?

So I am very much against this as it's a can of worms.

It doesn't deal with authentication, doesn't deal with manual port mappings (how the hell am I supposed to know what port did someone map on the router), doesn't deal with reverse proxies or anything else.
Supporting any of this would be pure madness, as we would have to start caring about these things and start wedging in settings to adjust them.

If this requires protocol changes, then I am even more against this, as all this does is tries to put a hyperlink in the page...

If you need to manage remote syncthing instances, please do the address setup/forwarding/dyndns /bookmarking the address or what not yourself.

The certificate we use the HTTPS has nothing to do with device ID's and it's a completely different certificate, so there is no way we can reasonably know what the self signed cert will look like...

Also, how are we going to "verify" it? Browsers do verification of certificates, and we have no say in that.

So I agree that adding GUI stuff to the protocol is out of scope. The protocol has always been about more than just the Syncthing implementation, and even we stray from that ideal now and then adding a specific GUI address field to it is going too far.

If you do remote administration of devices I think it’s reasonable to expect you to know what port you have the GUI on, while the IP might plausibly change now and then. Being able to add a port to the config and have the GUI generate a link feels roughly on par with being able to give the device a name of your choosing - a local decision for convenience. And it’s not super intrusive. So I think we could do that.

Right, I get it, so this is done on my own device.
I think that's ok.

Regarding the certificate, your device might be behind a genuine syncthing.mycompany.com domain, that is trusted by the browsers, and you might not want to click through a warning every time.
On the other hand, web certs are usually valid for 1-2 years (or even less with LetsEncrypt et al).
Device ID is a hash of the device certificate, which includes expiry date et al.

So your suggestion either forces everyone to click through the security warning in the browsers (as your device ID cert is self signed with "infinite" expiry and never accepted by the browsers), or forces you to rewire your cluster every 1-2 years, as your certificate expires and forces you to gain a new device ID. (because web certs never have "infinite" expiry).

Anyways, I'll reopen this as I guess there is consensus on the potential feature, which is add an advanced config option for each device called webUI port, which when non-zero, which converts something (device name) to an href pointing to `<address connected to if connected via TCP>:<port specified in the config>`.

rename.from: Advertise GUI link to other nodes (feature request)
rename.to: Allow specifying remote expected web UI port which would generate a href somewhere

body: Makes perfect sense to me now. Thanks for the clarification.
Is this still open? it is from 2018

Status indication is open and so it is. Unless one can't repro an issue, found a PR/commit that fixed it but failed to close the issue or believes a request is no longer relevant due to other changes, age is not a reason to mistrust the status indicator (I believe we have much older issues still).
I want to work on this. Assign it to me.
We don't assign tickets per-se. First PR to close it wins :)
Can someone help me decided how to write a test for this? It seems the functionality is mostly going to change in the frontend. Is it okay if I the commit does not include a backend test.
Yeah, I wouldn't expect one. (Though I guess a bonus point could be if the GUI probes for the port actually being open on the other side before displaying the link, perhaps.)
Would I have to write the javascript to probe for the port? Is there already something written in the backend to probe?
There's nothing in the backend, and the interesting test is anyway whether the browser can connect, not really the syncthing process (which might well be on the other side of the planet).
